title: noUselessUndefinedInitialization
description: |
  Disallow initializing variables to `undefined`.
---
import { Tabs, TabItem } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

<Tabs>
<TabItem label="JavaScript (and super languages)" icon="seti:javascript">
**Since**: `v1.7.2`
:::note
- Diagnostic Category: [`lint/complexity/noUselessUndefinedInitialization`](/reference/diagnostics#diagnostic-category)
- This rule has a **safe** fix.
:::

Sources: 
- Same as: <a href="https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/no-undef-init" target="_blank"><code>no-undef-init</code></a>

## Description
Disallow initializing variables to `undefined`.

A variable that is declared and not initialized to any value automatically gets the value of `undefined`.
It’s considered a best practice to avoid initializing variables to `undefined`.

Please note that any inline comments attached to the initialization value or variable will be moved at the end of the variable declaration on auto-fix.
Please be also aware that this differs from Eslint's behaviour.

## Examples

### Invalid

```js
var a = undefined;
```

```js
let b = undefined, c = 1, d = 2;
```

```js
for (let i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
	let i = undefined;
```

```js
let f = /**/undefined/**/ ;
```

### Valid

```js
var a = 1;
```

```js
class Foo {
	bar = undefined;
}
```

## How to configure
```json title="biome.json"
{
	"linter": {
		"rules": {
			"complexity": {
				"noUselessUndefinedInitialization": "error"
			}
		}
	}
}

```
